Earlier that morning, at approximately 9:28? AM, Lee Meredith, a Subrogation Recovery Analyst with The Rawlings Company, replied: “Thanks, there appears to be $18,606.51 in paid claims. I will confirm that amount ASAP.” Meredith’s message included his contact details: Phone 502-530-4605, Fax 502-753-7248, and the organization’s address: The Rawlings Company LLC, PO Box 2000, La Grange, KY 40031, with the DM15 email address DM15@rawlingscompany.com. The email also carried an important confidentiality notice: “IMPORTANT WARNING: This message is intended only for the use of the person or entity to which it is addressed and may contain information that may be privileged, confidential, and/or constitutes protected health information ('PHI') which is subject to protection under state and federal law. If the reader of this message is not the intended recipient, or the employee or agent responsible to deliver it to the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any review, dissemination, distribution, printing or copying of this information is STRICTLY PROHIBITED. If you have received this message in error, please notify us (DM15@rawlingscompany.com) immediately and delete the related message.”

From Jessa Galosmo, the message continued with: “From: Jessa Galosmo” “Sent: Thursday, February 13, 2025 9:25 AM” “To: Lee Meredith” “Subject: 15 7801066” and included the external-origin warning: “WARNING: This email originated outside of The Rawlings Group. DO NOT CLICK links or attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Please contact the Helpdesk if you have any questions.” The body of that message read: “Hi, Please see attached files.” It concluded with Jessa’s signature: “All the best, Jessa Galosmo Whaley Law Firm Ph: (502)357-9975 Fax: (502)364-9363,” and appears again with the same sign-off and contact details.

In summary, the case file involves Owen Lindsey in the 12-01-2024 MVA, with case reference 15 7801066. On February 13, 2025, Jessa Galosmo requested a lien ledger from Lee Meredith, who replied that there were $18,606.51 in paid claims and would confirm the amount. The email exchanges included confidentiality and external-origin warnings, and Jessa followed up with attachments, signing off as indicated.

Case: Owen-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024. Client: Owen Lindsey.

In this matter involving the Lindsey family and a motor vehicle accident dated December 1, 2024, communications circulated in early February and March of 2025 regarding medical treatment status and lien payments. On February 4, 2025, Chandler Wolfe, a branch claims representative for the Kentucky/Pennsylvania regional PIP office, sent an email asking for updates on any additional medical treatment or directions for Jeremy Lindsey, Elizabeth Lindsey, Chase Lindsey, and Owen Lindsey. He noted that, to date, the only medical bills received were for Ms. Elizabeth Lindsey. Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm replied later that morning, indicating that they were working on the matter.

Later in February, Jessa’s communication reiterated the ongoing effort to obtain updates on the Lindsey family’s medical treatment and directions, with Jessa signing off as all the best from the Whaley Law Firm. Chandler Wolfe followed up again in this period, and his message referenced the firm’s Customer Center, which would allow access to claim information anytime, anywhere.

On March 7, 2025, a forward was sent from Jessa Galosmo to attorneys Aaron Whaley and Justin Chumbley regarding file 300-0793616-2024 for Jeremy C. Lindsey. The forwarded message, from Chandler Wolfe, asked whether he should issue payments on the liens that had been received for Owen Lindsey and Chase Lindsey. Wolfe’s contact details were provided: he is with the Kentucky/PIP team, with a phone number 800.346.0346 ext. 54628, fax 517.886.8754, and email KentuckyPIP.clm@aoins.com, operating from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. EST. The message also included Wolfe’s professional signature and standard firm branding.

In response, Jessa informed Chandler that “Jeremy and Owen are already done treating,” while “Elizabeth and Chase are still getting treatment.” This status update was part of the March 7 exchange, following Chandler’s inquiry about lien payments and the prior February email thread in which only Elizabeth’s medical bills had been received.

Throughout the correspondence, the firm noted the existence of a Customer Center to enable claim information access at any time, and Jessa’s communications consistently closed with courteous regards and the Whaley Law Firm contact information, including phone and fax numbers.

On May 7, 2025 at 11:52:30 AM (Eastern Time), Aaron Whaley emailed Emily Pernice, with Owen Lindsey’s Filevine project address and the SouthCentralBodilyInjury.clm inbox CC’d, to summarize the settlement allocations: Jeremy would receive $2,000; Owen Lindsey would receive $16,000; Chase would receive $16,000; and Elizabeth would receive $16,000. The message was titled Re: #300-793616-2024.

Earlier in the thread, on May 6, 2025 at 2:13 PM, Emily Pernice asked Aaron to confirm the amounts allocated to each person—Jeremy, Elizabeth, Owen, and Chase—so the allocations could be finalized.

The thread also shows prior back-and-forth in late April 2025. The thread includes subsequent May 6 emails in which Aaron and Emily continued to correspond about the same issue, with Aaron sending a follow-up on May 6 and Emily reiterating the need to confirm the allocation details.

Across the exchanges, the case involves a motor vehicle accident (MVA) related matter for Owen Lindsey, with subrogation considerations and a potential settlement with the at-fault party being explored in relation to Auto Owners, and a final allocation of the settlements among four individuals—Jeremy, Elizabeth, Owen, and Chase—being established as described above.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Owen-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024. Client: Owen Lindsey.

On May 7, 2025, an internal email forward was sent regarding the Owen Lindsey motor vehicle accident case. The message to Jennifer Howard at Progressive and to Owen Lindsey’s Filevine project address noted that UIOM is waiving subrogation, and asked what else was needed to cut the checks. This forward was part of the thread labeled “Fwd: #300-0793616-2024.”

In the forwarded chain, Emily Pernice, a Bodily Injury claims specialist with South Central Bodily Injury, replied that subrogation would be waived. Her reply stated simply, “We are waiving subrogation,” and included her professional signature with contact information. This exchange followed a prior series of messages beginning several days earlier.

Earlier in the thread, on April 29, 2025, Aaron Whaley asked Emily Pernice whether Auto Owners had decided to permit settlement with the at-fault party. Emily had responded that the matter was still under review for subrogation potential, and she noted that a full Coats (Coots) Notice had been received on April 22, 2025 by email, promising an immediate update once the review was complete.

Over the course of the first week of May 2025, allocation details were discussed. On May 6, 2025 at 10:58 AM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Emily, copying Owen Lindsey and others, asking for confirmation of the amounts allocated to each person: Jeremy, Elizabeth, Owen, and Chase. The proposed allocations at that time were Jeremy: $2,000; Owen: $16,000; Chase: $16,000; Elizabeth: $16,000. Emily followed up later that day at 2:13 PM with a request to confirm the amounts allocated to each person (Jeremy, Elizabeth, Owen, Chase).

On May 7, 2025, a separate exchange reiterated the allocations, with Aaron listing: Jeremy: $2,000; Owen: $16,000; Chase: $16,000; Elizabeth: $16,000. At 11:56 AM, Emily wrote that she had thought the total underlying amount for the Lindsays was $49,500 and requested reconfirmation. In a subsequent note, she added, “it is sorry I forgot. Do $1500 for Jeremy.” This indicated a proposed adjustment to Jeremy’s allocation from $2,000 to $1,500, while the other three allocations remained at $16,000 each, though the thread also shows the competing total of $49,500 versus the sum of the line-item allocations.

Throughout these exchanges, the thread consistently reflects the ongoing process of subrogation review, the status of a settlement with the at-fault party, and the allocations among involved parties (Jeremy, Elizabeth, Owen, and Chase). The May 7, 2025 correspondence confirms that UIOM was to waive subrogation and seeks to finalize the necessary details to proceed with issuing checks. The Filevine and email records also include the relevant contact details and references to claim centers and notices, as described in the messages.

Case information: This record concerns the Owen-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024 case, with client Owen Lindsey.

On May 9, 2025, at 11:45:38 AM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email about handling and hold-harmless matters, addressed to Jennifer Howard of Progressive Direct Insurance and cc’d to the Owen Lindsey Filevine project email address. In that message, Whaley stated, “I will handle and hold harmless.” His firm’s contact details were included: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Earlier, on May 9, 2025, at 11:16 AM, Jennifer Howard replied to the external thread. She confirmed receipt of the email and then asked to confirm the proposed breakdown of the client’s bodily injury (BI) settlements: Jeremy Lindsey $1,500; Elizabeth Lindsey $16,000; Chase Lindsey $16,000; Owen Lindsey $16,000. She noted that she had been placed on notice of health insurance liens on the Lindsey family and asked whether these liens should be addressed by Progressive or deducted from the settlement proceeds. Howard provided her title as Claims Specialist-Sr. for Progressive Direct Insurance Company and supplied her contact information: P.O. Box 94670, Cleveland, OH 44101-9919, 859-629-4740 (W) and 833-905-1745 (F).

The email chain also shows the prior progression of communication about subrogation and settlement, beginning with a May 7, 2025 exchange. On May 7, 2025 at 12:10 PM, Aaron Whaley forwarded to Jennifer Howard and the Owen Lindsey Filevine address a message from himself to Jennifer, noting, “Jennifer, see below. UIOM is waiving subrogation. What else do you need to get the checks cut? Thanks.” That same day, Emily Pernice of South Central Bodily Injury (AIC) replied at 12:07 PM, confirming, “We are waiving subrogation.” Pernice’s signature block identified her as AIC, AIC-M, AINS, and included her contact details: p: 800.346.0346 ext. 55169; f: 517.327.2391; e: pernice.emily@aoins.com, with hours 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. EST, plus a note about a Customer Center for claim access.

The thread shows earlier May 7 communications detailing allocation amounts. At 11:53 AM on May 7, Aaron Whaley wrote to Pernice and CC’d Owen Lindsey and the SouthCentralBodilyInjury.clm address with a proposed distribution: Jeremy $2,000; Owen $16,000; Chase $16,000; Elizabeth $16,000, in response to an earlier inquiry about the allocations for the Lindsey parties. At 11:56 AM, Emily Pernice replied that she thought the total underlying amount for the Lindseys was $49,500 and asked for reconfirmation. Whaley replied, “it is sorry I forgot. Do $1,500 for Jeremy.” Pernice then reiterated her request to reconfirm the total, and Whaley again referenced the allocations: Jeremy $1,500, Owen $16,000, Chase $16,000, Elizabeth $16,000.

Between May 6 and May 7, Pernice sent multiple requests for confirmation of allocations. On May 6, 2025 at 2:13 PM, Pernice asked for confirmation of the amounts allocated to each person (Jeremy, Elizabeth, Owen, Chase), with a proposed distribution that initially listed: Jeremy $2,000, Owen $16,000, Chase $16,000, Elizabeth $16,000. Earlier that day, she had sent a similar inquiry, and at 10:58 AM Whaley had written to Pernice with a courtesy check-in about the matter. The chain shows ongoing discussion about subrogation potential and references to a “full Coots Notice” that was received on April 22, 2025 by email.

The record notes that, on April 29, 2025, Whaley emailed Pernice to inquire whether Auto Owners had decided whether to permit settlement with the at-fault party. Pernice replied on April 29 that the matter was still under review for subrogation potential and that, once the review was complete, they would update, noting that the full Coots Notice had been received.

In sum, the communications reflect a process from late April through early May 2025 in which the subrogation potential was reviewed, UIOM indicated it would waive subrogation, and a proposed BI settlement breakdown for the Lindsey family was discussed and revised multiple times. By May 9, 2025, the parties had arrived at a proposed BI distribution of Jeremy Lindsey $1,500 and Elizabeth Lindsey, Chase Lindsey, and Owen Lindsey each at $16,000, with a direct acknowledgment from Progressive about the need to address health insurance liens. Jennifer Howard’s May 9 response confirmed the breakdown and reiterated the lien concern, asking whether the liens should be addressed by Progressive or deducted from settlement proceeds. The May 9 exchange also confirms the ongoing involvement of Aaron Whaley on behalf of the Lindsey family and underscores that the matter remains coordinated among Whaley Law Firm, Progressive Direct Insurance Company, Emily Pernice of South Central Bodily Injury, and Owen Lindsey’s file.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Owen-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024
Client: Owen Lindsey

In the Owen Lindsey motor vehicle accident matter, a series of communications occurred between late April and mid-May 2025 concerning settlement amounts, subrogation, affidavits, and Medicare eligibility. On May 15, 2025, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent a forwarding note noting “No medicare” and that Elizabeth Lindsey would sign the affidavits. This message accompanied the external thread regarding settlement with the Lindsey family related to file #300-0793616-2024.

Earlier, on May 12, 2025 at 10:32 a.m., Jennifer Howard, a claims specialist for Progressive Direct Insurance, asked via email which parent should be named on the notarized affidavits for Chase and Owen, since their settlements would require affidavits. She also inquired whether any member of the Lindsey family might be eligible to receive Medicare benefits, and she attached the settlement releases for the Lindsey family.

In the days prior, communications circulated about subrogation and settlement structure. On May 9, 2025 at 11:46 a.m., Aaron Whaley replied that he would handle and hold harmless. His message included his contact information and indicated that he would take responsibility for that aspect of the matter. Earlier that same day, Jennifer Howard had engaged in a back-and-forth about the settlements’ composition and the handling of health insurance liens. On May 9 at 11:16 a.m., she confirmed the need to verify the breakdown for the Lindsey clients’ bodily injury settlements and asked for confirmation of the following allocations: Jeremy Lindsey, $1,500; Elizabeth Lindsey, $16,000; Chase Lindsey, $16,000; Owen Lindsey, $16,000. She also noted that health insurance liens had been placed on the Lindsey family and asked whether she should address them from settlement proceeds or handle them another way. She signed off with her Progressive contact information.

The discussion continued on May 7 and May 6, with multiple updates about subrogation and settlement allocations. On May 7 at 12:10 p.m., Aaron Whaley told Jennifer, “Jennifer, see below. UIOM is waiving subrogation. What else do you need to get the checks cut? Thanks.” The same day, Emily Pernice of South Central Bodily Injury (AIC) replied, “We are waiving subrogation.” Emily provided her contact information and noted standard business hours. Earlier that morning, at 11:59 a.m., Aaron advised, “it is sorry I forgot. Do $1500 for Jeremy.” At 11:56 a.m., Emily asked for reconfirmation, stating she believed the total underlying amount for the Lindsey family was $49,500 and requested confirmation. At 11:53 a.m., Aaron had provided a proposed allocation: Jeremy $2,000; Owen $16,000; Chase $16,000; Elizabeth $16,000. Emily reaffirmed with a follow-up later in the day about the total underlying amount and the need to reconfirm.

On May 6, 2025, Emily asked Aaron to confirm the amounts allocated to each person (Jeremy, Elizabeth, Owen, Chase). Aaron replied at 10:58 a.m. with a brief check-in, and later that afternoon at 2:13 p.m. Emily requested confirmation of the allocations again, consistent with the prior discussion.

The thread traces further back to April 29, 2025. At 10:46 a.m., Emily indicated that the matter was still under review for subrogation potential and advised that full Coots Notice had been received by email on 04/22/2025. She promised updates once the review was complete. Prior to that, at 10:39 a.m., Aaron had followed up with Emily to see whether Auto Owners (insurer) had decided whether to permit settlement with the at-fault party.

Summary of key points preserved in the correspondence:
- The Lindsey family’s settlement structure was under negotiation, with proposals for Jeremy Lindsey, Elizabeth Lindsey, Chase Lindsey, and Owen Lindsey.
- The preliminary allocations circulated included Jeremy receiving amounts in the range of $1,500 to $2,000, and Elizabeth, Chase, and Owen each receiving approximately $16,000, with totals discussed around $49,500 as the underlying settlement pool.
- Subrogation was a central issue: UIOM was noted as waiving subrogation, and Emily Pernice confirmed the waiver from the subrogation perspective.
- Health insurance liens were identified as needing addressal, with questions about whether Progressive should handle them or deduct from settlement proceeds.
- Notarized affidavits were required for Chase and Owen, and it was necessary to decide which Lindsey parent should be named on those affidavits.
- Medicare eligibility was considered for the Lindsey family, with Jennifer asking who, if anyone, might qualify.
- Elizabeth Lindsey was identified as the person who would sign affidavits, and a directive noted “No medicare” in the May 15, 2025 message.

Overall, the communications reflect a coordinated effort among counsel and the insurer to finalize the Lindsey settlements, confirm subrogation waivers, allocate settlement amounts among family members, prepare the necessary affidavits, and address health insurance liens and Medicare considerations, with the intent to issue settlement checks once all conditions, including notarization and lien resolution, were satisfied.
